subject: Redfish: Support Host Log Entries
commitMessage:
Redfish: Support Host Log Entries

This commit is designing and implementing a new logging service in
Redfish to expose host serial console logs.The goal is that clients
can talk to bmc via Redfish and get a real-time console. It will improve
the debuggability of BMCs.

We will add three paths to redfish tree to implement the feature:
1. /redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/HostLogger
2. /redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/HostLogger/Entries
3. /redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/HostLogger/Entries/<str>

To use this feature, we expect to use phosphor-hostlogger(stream mode)
+ rsyslog + bmcweb. Phosphor-hostlooger in stream mode forwards the byte
stream into rsyslog via the imuxsock module. The log is persisted via
the omfile module as soon as collected. It makes Host Logger leverage
exsisting tools (rsyslog and logrotate). Then we can expose host serial
console logs via bmcweb.

This feature can be enabled or disabled by setting the option
"redfish-host-logger", and the default value is "enabled". If you don't
want to expose host serial console logs, you need to turn the value to
"disabled".

RedfishServiceValidator results:
/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/HostLogger
pass: 4
passGet: 1
skipOptional: 9

/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/HostLogger/Entries
pass: 24
passGet: 1
skipOptional: 1

/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/HostLogger/Entries/<str>
pass: 7
passGet: 1
skipOptional: 15

Sample Output:
curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/HostLogger/Entries
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/HostLogger/Entries",
  "@odata.type": "#LogEntryCollection.LogEntryCollection",
  "Description": "Collection of HostLogger Entries",
  "Members": [
    {
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/HostLogger/Entries/1",
      "@odata.type": "#LogEntry.v1_4_0.LogEntry",
      "EntryType": "Event",
      "Id": "1",
      "Message": "[   57.061546] gq 0000:16:00.0 eth0: link up, 100 Gbps, no PAUSE",
      "MessageArgs": [
        "[   57.061546] gq 0000:16:00.0 eth0: link up, 100 Gbps, no PAUSE"
      ],
      "MessageId": "OpenBMC.0.1.SerialLogAdded",
      "Name": "HostLogger Entries",
      "Severity": "OK"
    },
  ...
  ],
  "Members@odata.count": 22,
  "Name": "HostLogger Entries"
}

Signed-off-by: SpencerKu <Spencer.Ku@quantatw.com>
Change-Id: I5a7873caa117400fb0a737588a50bd743e8b5063

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as bf888502a247d8374c70e7ceddc9862bf0ad88bd by Ed Tanous
We don't need the SerialLogAdded message registry until we start to use Redfish Events, right?
This question has been discussed in previous PR, please refer to the link: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/39093/4/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#1754
OK, so a MessageId is required for the Event type of logs? Are we accepting this name here?

nit: move the declaration near to what it is used.

```
std::string filename = it.path().filename();
```
Done
Prefer return value over output parameter if possible.
Done
what about '\n'?
Consider using find_first_of to search '\r' or '\n' at the same time?

'\n' is handle by gzgets function which shall attempt to read data until a newline character(\n) has been uncompressed into buf. https://refspecs.linuxbase.org/LSB_3.0.0/LSB-Core-generic/LSB-Core-generic/zlib-gzgets-1.html
I see. So logEntry will never contain '\n'.
ditto: prefer returning a nlohmann::json object directly if possible.
Other similar function like "fillEventLogEntryJson" or "fillBMCJournalLogEntryJson" use the same method here. So keep the style here may be better?
If that's the case I am OK with keeping it consistent.
We don't need the MessageRegistry IIUC, right? Does it violate the validator?
If no, can we remove all the parts related to MessageRegistry? It doesn't give us more information than the message itself.
This question has been discussed in previous PR, please refer to the link: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/39093/4/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#1754
LGTM.
Can we add more error message here?
Sure, is it enough after modifying?

I meant can we add the error message into the response? 

Also we should keep "messages::internalError(asyncResp->res);" though we added BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR IIUC, right?

I doesn't research about it a lot but i think we need to register a new error message like this: https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/commit/dd28ba829972906cbe2d372cf4ec00fdf82fbb83

Should we need to add?
Ack. I am OK with adding it in the future.

Sorry, after I search for the register, I find that the commit above is adding base message register which have to follow DMTF SPEC. So i think we can not add new message here. I keep the   original method here.
Is the latest log file compressed as well? Or GzFile is smart enough so when a file is not compressed, it reads it directly without decompression?

Yes, gzopen handle this problem. If path refers to an uncompressed file, and mode refers to a read mode, gzopen() shall attempt to open the file and return a gzFile object suitable for reading directly from the file without any decompression. https://refspecs.linuxbase.org/LSB_3.0.0/LSB-Core-generic/LSB-Core-generic/zlib-gzopen-1.html
We should keep characters other than EOL as is.
Done
should we break directly if "entryCount > skip + top"?
No, it still need to count the total number of log entry to present "Members@odata.count".

How does the ordering work here? Consider the following case,

```
# console plaintext
message4
message5

# console_0 compressed
message2
message3


# console_1 compressed
message0
message1
```

We shall get either [msg4, msg3, ..., msg0] or [msg0, msg1, ..., msg4], however, the codes here get us "[msg4, msg5, msg2, msg3, msg0, msg1]", am I correct? It isn't OK. We don't have timestamps here, the relative order matters.

I think the default directory_entry::path order result confuse me, because the log entry present result is correct. But add a sorting function is better. I already add sorting function in "getHostLoggerFiles" by decreasing. Thank you point out this question.
Just to confirm, now LogEntries are ordered from oldest to newest, right?
Yes, i think it is find now.
Please leave msgs as is.
Done
50/72 line wrap please.
Done

Things that I see missing here:

1. Why is this feature useful?
2. What changes does this make to the Redfish tree?
3. How is this expected to be used?
4. What options are being added?  Why would someone enable or disable this option?

Please answer these questions in your commit message.
Thanks for the suggestion, i will update it in next patch.
I follow the suggestions and modify the commit message, please take a look, thanks.
whitespace issue.
Done
This branch isn't needed.  just call clear().  If the buf is already empty, it will be no-op.
Thank you for the suggestion.
According to the docs, gzgets returns a pointer to the buf object.  We need to resize the string based on this pointer, otherwise this method could return UB.
Understand, here i use data length to resize the string at line 53.
Does this need checked?  I'm not following why this is here.
Because when "gzgets" function read end of file, it will also return Z_NULL. In this case, it is not an error, so i add if statement here.
I wonder if this needs its own registry, or we shouldn't be filling in MessageId at all?  I need to think more on that.
My understanding is we don't actually need MessageId for serial logs, since we aren't adding extra context here.
I think i have the same idea with Nan here.
Let's delete it to save some bandwidth.
Any updates?
I remove the code which relate to message registry.

undefined behavior.  This is taking a reference to an rvalue object.

nit: given that this is such a long name, can you initialize this without using an = to make the code nicer to read.

Sorry, I’m not sure I understand. According to SPEC, the member types also use reference.  https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem/directory_iterator
Is i using wrong method here?

I missed it in the first round of review. The object created on you right side `std::filesystem::directory_iterator` will be destroyed and you will get a pointer which points to a destroyed object.

Ed suggest you use `std::filesystem::directory_iterator logPath(hostLoggerFilePath, ec)`;

Any updates?

The example you see in https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem/directory_iterator is using range based for loop. https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/range-for. It creates a temporary iterator in each loop, which is valid. It is different from the problem we described here.
Thank for the detail information! I confuse with other problem. Follow the suggestion and modify the code here.
nit: just if (ec) please
Done
The files will be in /var/log/consoleN?  Shouldn't they be in a folder, like /var/log/console/logN?  That seems like it would be more similar to other linux services.
Thanks for your suggestion. I modify the file folder path to /var/log/console and the file name will be log, log.1.gz, log.2.gz... and so on.
no need to clear.
Done
nit: typo.
Done

This looks like most of it is copied from the other fillEventLogEntryJson method.  Is there a reason that other one couldn't be used?  I'd prefer to avoid duplicating the code.


I wrote the below comments before I realized that this was just copied and pasted, then modified, which explains a lot of the strange patterns.  Once this comment is implemented, a bunch of other comments might be irrelevant.

In the early development this function handle lots of things, but for now it just handle registry message. If we finally decide to remove the registry message which discuss in other comment, i think this function will do the different thing with fillEventLogEntryJson. So i simplify the code here.
This line confuses me.  This line constructs an array of size 1, then on line 1880 we loop over this array of 1.  Can you either simplify the code, or comment why we're doing this?
I directly use msg to replace argStr here.
Please invert this check, and move it up to line 1870.  Also, shouldn't this be returning?  If message pointer didn't get filled in, then registryMsg will be empty, and we'll do the wrong thing.
Understand, i add a return here to check if we get an error during getting message from registry.
nit.  Please put the increment on its own line.  Doing the preincrement in line is harder to read and reason about, even though this is correct as written.
I see, i remove the increment and rewrite the function.
This needs to fail early.  message should never be nullptr here.  Also, as written this is making a copy of the string, which can be avoided if you fail early and return an error.
I see, i move it up to line 1874.

Please read the redfish specification on how skip and top are supposed to work.  I suspect this was copied from the other log service, which technically does it incorrectly.  We'll need to implement to the spec here, to avoid having to fix it later.

Reading from http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.12.0.html#query-parameters (it is not the latest but I found hmtl format more convenient to share), we should firstly skip ${skip} entries, then collect ${top} entires, and finally return them in the response.

The implementation seems correct in this regards. But I see some problems in the IDs. IDs of entries should stay the same no matter what the query parameters are. Is that the problem you are talking about?
I modify the ID count method, and now it will not influence by top and skip value. Does it solved the problem
I guess only when entryCount <= skip we need the `idCount = idCount + msgBuf.size();`. But yes, I believe it fixed the problem.
ditto
Ack
Should we store the pointer gzgets returns and use std::distance to get the length rather than strlen? Will the string contain '\0'?
Any updates?

Here i use std::string::data() to catch so it will not contain "\0". For the string length problem, because it will fill null character if there is no data, strlen() can help to filter the null character. If we use begin and end then to get std::distance, the return size will be still 8192 here(fill with null character). https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/byte/strlen

Talked to Ed offline. gzgets is not the proper API here since it requires the uncompressed buffer null-terminated. Ed found there's gzread which returns the length of read buffer explicitly. Please use it instead.

https://refspecs.linuxbase.org/LSB_3.0.0/LSB-Core-generic/LSB-Core-generic/zlib-gzread-1.html

Yes, "gzread" gets the buffer length, but the return value means whole gz file size (eof has been reached). "gzgets" function here is trying to get a line from file (until a newline character has been uncompressed into buf), so strlen(buf.data() means length of a line, not whole gz file's length.

Does gzgets handle '\0' in the uncompressed buffer? I believe gzgets assumes there's no '\0'. 

"gzread" should return the size of data it reads, right? not necessarily the whole gz file size if the passed len is shorter than the entire size. We should use gzread since it returns the actual length of read data so we can resize our string. From there, we can then split the string by EOL.

The major issue here is the uncompressed buffer might have '\0'. You strlen() won't give the the correct size. E.g. "123\0123\0" as a std::string is of length 8; strlen() will give you 3 I believe.
I use gzread to rewrite the code. Use vector to store whole log entries from log files, and use std::vector::at to get the message. Please take a look, thanks!

Why do we have a file size limit? I understand we need to set a limit to the length of the buffer we read at each iteration, but we can read as many characters as the file contains, right (assume memory is not the bottleneck)?

Yes, i think buffer limit size is what i actually want to mention here. Here I just want to tell if file size larger than buffer size, it will occur some error or message not complete issue. It will happen when file rotate is not quick enough. Now the rotate script will detect file size every 15 seconds, if file size increase and larger than 16k(default setting) in the 15 seconds, then the previous issue will happen. I can modify the detect interval shorter to fix the issue, or define buffer limit size more larger to fix the issue. Or other method I doesn't notice?

We should be able to handle arbitrary file size (we read some size of buffer at each time). 

The buffer limit is not related to 16k limit in the log rotation configuration. We don't need to read the whole file in one read.

Please remove the comments related to file size limit in log rotation configuration.

According to offline talking, I rewrite the code to fix the issue that if message is too long and separate to two files. And about the buffer limit size, since we will go though whole file, I just define limit size to 1024 as a temp.
See above, I prefer to say bufferLimitSize.
Yes, i will change the name.
Done

I don't understand the logic here. 

gzread should read at most fileLimitSize characters, right? So bytesRead <= fileLimitSize should always hold?
If fileLimitSize is big enough, bytesRead <= fileLimitSize should always hold. Please refer to the previous comment.

OK. So please add a comment like

"bytesRead is supposed to be equal to bufferLimitSize in normal cases; it can be smaller if we reach the end of the file; otherwise, we must have a failure."
Done
Sorry i miss the problem, will fix in next patch
Add the buffer resize here to fix the problem.
nit: should it be one file?
I just want to mention if Message1\rMessage2\rMessage3\r\n in one line, it include 3 log entries.
why do check !empty() here? We should just append to the back, right?
Assume the log entry is like "Message\r\n", than the string will split to "Message" and "". So need this checker to remove the "".
LGTM.
With above comments, I believe here the condition should be if (initialPos < buffer.size()).

The if statement here is try to handle if file size larger than buffer size, than the last message will separate. So store the message and prepend to first message in next reading. If buffer size is enough then the issue should not happen.
Yes, I think your comment is more directly than originally. Has been modified.

Wouldn't this cause our logs to be missing when multiple newlines are emitted in a row?

I think this case has been handled. If the string is like "Message1
Message2

", then it will be split as "Message1", "Message2", and "", and the last one "" will be filtered.

I guess Ed's point is about whether we should keep consecutive newlines. There's no guarantee that console or kernel logs don't output consecutive newlines.

```
whatever logs go here, followed by 3 newlines\n
\n
whatever logs go here
```

In this code, the above logs become

```
whatever logs go here, followed by 3 newlines\n
whatever logs go here
```

I suggest we not delete these newlines. 

To do that, IIUC, we can store the previous delimiter, when logEntry is empty && the previous delimiter is not '\r' && the current delimiter is not '\n', we just push back a "\n".

So we have
1. "\r\n": act as a single delimiter
2. "\n\n": a "\n" is collected as a log
3. "\n\r": a "\n" is collected as a log
4. "\r\r": a "\n" is collected as a log
Add a checker to handle consecutive delimiters.

Can we do something more clear here, and parse the number to an integer, then sort on that?  That seems significantly easier to read than this, because frankly.... I'm not really sure what's going on here.

This is basically a customized comparator: firstly sort files by length of their file names; if two file names have the same length, sort them by alphabetical order. 

The end effect is that: ".gz123" > ".gz3" > ".gz2".

My best guess is that we're generating a tuple of size, string, then relying on the fact that tuples can be implicitly sorted based on the order of the elements. What if the first file is 1GB?  This check doesn't prevent us from running out of memory.  I suspect this check needs to go into the gzGetLines as an argument for "limit"


Also, the way this is written doesn't work with the paging.  This method needs to be aware of skip and top so it can correctly only read in the files that it needs.  Otherwise, if we generated logs that were > 256KB, there'd be no way to read them.

As a test, I'd recommend dropping the limit to something much easier to generate (maybe 1k?) and make sure you can still page out the logs, but as written, this code looks like it can't.
